children.value: Here's a straightforward implementation of a React hook that allows you to set, modify and remove URL query parameters. There is already a popular and high-quality implementation by
. I was going to use that at first but about two-thirds of the way through reading its source code I decided that it's a little overengineered for my simple use case. Peter's
offers React Router and Reach Router integrations, uses

internally to pass their history objects down to subscribing components, has dependencies on external packages and requires you to import and then specify types (numbers, strings, arrays, etc.) for any query parameter you specify. All I want to do is append the odd string to a URL. I'm happy to rely on simple browser APIs to do it for me. (Should I need to store more sophisticated data types than strings to a URL search string in the future, I guess I'll just try my luck with
So I decided to start from scratch and roll my own hook. Considering that it ended up taking only around 30 lines of code, I think it was the right decision for my use case. Here's the code:
which specifies on a per-hook basis whether passing
as the value should delete the parameter from the URL query, as well as a string
that determines whether changes to the query should replace or be appended to the browser history. With the default
, the user will get back to the previous page immediately when using the browser's back button.
, will require one back button press for every time
Here's an example of how to use this hook to filter a list of posts on a blog page by tag.
component in the last highlighted line simply uses
tag would set the active tag to
so that clicking it will remove the
query parameter from the address bar completely.
